Looks good to me.
Note that this sets minimum supported version to 4.2 (at least).

> Looks good to me.
> Note that this sets minimum supported version to 4.2 (at least).

That's a good point – the enhancements to `Hashable` came in [Swift 4.2](https://swift.org/blog/swift-4-2-released/).

I would expect the most recent version of Xcode to produce no warnings out of the box and folks who require support for versions of Swift earlier than 4.2 remain on older versions of Thrift. But, that's just my opinion!

> That's a good point – the enhancements to `Hashable` came in [Swift 4.2](https://swift.org/blog/swift-4-2-released/).
> 
> I would expect the most recent version of Xcode to produce no warnings out of the box 
me too
> and folks who require support for versions of Swift earlier than 4.2 remain on older versions of Thrift. But, that's just my opinion!

I am new here, so I don't know the policy... if desired, it's possible to use #if (swift<4.2) #else #endif. Obviously, it may be just a waste of work.

In our team we switched to XCode 11.4 and Swift 5.2 (see #2069) , so I personally don't care :)

And again, I appreciate this fix, as it annoyed me and I planned to fix it myself when I find some time.
@allengeorge I leave this up to you
@Jens-G  is it possible to recieve some reaction on pull-request?
OK. Thank you.

It's been ages since I looked at C, but, looking at the underlying definition @wyjwang appears correct: `g_array_append_vals` does copy the object onto the end of the array via `memcpy`. (I guess intuitively that makes sense; arrays are contiguous access).
@Jens-G How would I retry the XCode 10.2 pdb job? It seems to have what's stopped the Travis CI job.
A test-case would be useful. Separately (and independent of this ticket) perhaps a `ENABLE_MEM_CHECK` gtk would allow us to catch problems in CI? Again, it's been ages since I worked in C.
Since the Rust-version has been updated to 1.36, I believe we should be able to reapply this.
cc @MikailBag Given that upstream has now updated the Rust version we use, I've reapplied your PR (cherry-picking your commit so that you don't lose attribution) and trying to apply it again.

There are quite a few PRs related to c_glib. I wish I had the knowledge to properly review them.

Hey all.

From what the patch author has submitted to [THRIFT-5144][] Jira, it's pretty clear that to reproduce the issue, you must **build with `-fsanitize=address`** and just run the existing tests. They'll fail with tons of ASAN reports; most of which are related to the bison or whatever parsing code (and I really hope that's a false positive).

ASAN reports mention `g_malloc` too on master; no mention of `g_malloc` with the patch applied:

    $ make -sC BUILD test
    $ grep g_malloc BUILD/Testing/Temporary/LastTest.log
    $
    $ # no output with the patch

but like this on master:

```
$ grep -C2 g_malloc BUILD/Testing/Temporary/LastTest.log
Direct leak of 184 byte(s) in 53 object(s) allocated from:
    #0 0x7f32f8f63b3a in __interceptor_malloc /build/gcc/src/gcc/libsanitizer/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:144
    #1 0x7f32f8d35ce9 in g_malloc (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x65ce9)
    #2 0x563ddfb090f3 in struct_constants_read_write /home/ulidtko/src/thrift/lib/c_glib/test/testserialization.c:49
    #3 0x7f32f8d19dee  (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x49dee)
--
Direct leak of 28 byte(s) in 7 object(s) allocated from:
    #0 0x7f32f8f63b3a in __interceptor_malloc /build/gcc/src/gcc/libsanitizer/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:144
    #1 0x7f32f8d35ce9 in g_malloc (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x65ce9)
    #2 0x563ddfb08c8a in enum_constants_read_write /home/ulidtko/src/thrift/lib/c_glib/test/testserialization.c:24
    #3 0x7f32f8d19dee  (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x49dee)
--
Direct leak of 17 byte(s) in 2 object(s) allocated from:
    #0 0x7f3e80d9ab3a in __interceptor_malloc /build/gcc/src/gcc/libsanitizer/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:144
    #1 0x7f3e80b6cce9 in g_malloc (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x65ce9)

SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: 17 byte(s) leaked in 2 allocation(s).
--
Direct leak of 32 byte(s) in 4 object(s) allocated from:
    #0 0x7f7cc9d9fb3a in __interceptor_malloc /build/gcc/src/gcc/libsanitizer/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:144
    #1 0x7f7cc9b71ce9 in g_malloc (/usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0+0x65ce9)

SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: 32 byte(s) leaked in 4 allocation(s).
```

[THRIFT-5144]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/THRIFT/issues/THRIFT-5144

Here's a script to quickly test it:
```sh
#!/bin/sh -x

cd "$(dirname "$0")" || exit

rm -rf BUILD && mkdir -p BUILD
rm -rf compiler/cpp/test/compiler/tmp*

cd BUILD; cmake \
    -Wno-dev \
    \
    -DWITH_AS3=OFF -DWITH_HASKELL=OFF -DWITH_CPP=OFF -DWITH_JAVA=OFF \
    -DWITH_JAVASCRIPT=OFF -DWITH_NODEJS=OFF -DWITH_PYTHON=OFF \
    -DWITH_OPENSSL=ON \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_AS3=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_HS=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_CPP=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_CL=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_HAXE=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_D=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_DART=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_DELPHI=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_ERL=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_GO=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_GV=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_HTML=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_JAVA=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_JAVAME=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_JS=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_JSON=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_LUA=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_NETSTD=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_OCAML=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_PERL=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_PHP=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_PY=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_RB=OFF  \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_RS=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_ST=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_SWIFT=OFF \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_XML=OFF -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_XSD=OFF \
    \
    -DTHRIFT_COMPILER_C_GLIB=ON \
    \
    `: -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="-fsanitize=address"` \
    `: -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS="-fsanitize=address"` \
    .. \
    && make -s all test check
```

I definitely recommend merging this PR.

No need to be sorry. You didn't break anyone else's work. These checks are here to prevent that.
It just means your change is not ready yet.

Change the line to:
```
     if (is_pointer_field(*m_iter)) {
```
and it'll be ok. I didn't check further tests, just compilation.

@Jens-G , done. I know why CI reports  errors and fails largely, because there are some .thrift files in the project that do not have const members and other members, but Makefile.am and CMakeLists.txt assume that they will generate corresponding _constants.xx and _types.xx files by default.

Although `pragma once` can simplify the code, `#ifndef` is more compatible and portable. 
@Jens-G what do you think.

Moving towards one build system (cmake) is a great effort, it's nice to see this happening in some capacity.  Unfortunately when builds break... merging is hard. :)

> Unfortunately when builds break... merging is hard. :)

Haha yes! I was actually hoping [you could help with the Gruntfile](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-5109?focusedCommentId=17083999&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-17083999)?

The "problem" now is not that the CMake build itself would be broken. The problem is that the Javascript build in autotools was not used on MSVC before, whereas in CMake I have now enabled Javascript on MSVC. And it fails, probably never worked.

This could and should be split off into a separate issue, unless you (or someone else) could fix the Javascript build?
The rest of this PR should be fine and should have worked from the start. The failing Javascript could just be disabled on AppVeyor.

I was going to suggest the same thing, but was distracted and didn't get back to it.

Since JS issue is unrelated to cmake (the issue is that JS can't be compiled on windows), one solution is to disable JS build on windows, and make another issue for JS.
@dcelasun I think this is a trivial change so didn't create a jira ticket first. If a jira ticket is still needed please let me know and I can create one.
LGTM. I'll merge once CI is finished.
The only failure in CI seems to be related to js
@dmaluka looks like this is causing tests to fail?
Yep. Looks like I need to change the scope of variables.
Since Thrift is already using C++11, do you think there's a compiler that supports that but not pragma once?

Any plans to add Swift tests? The (now-deleted, unfortunately) Objective-C libraries, which the Swift code was based on, also didn't have tests, and a major bug was introduced that broke the server implementation that went undetected/reported for years. We fixed it in our local branch, but  can't upstream it. I think those who are using the Swift library should consider implementing tests if possible, to prevent regressions. Relying on manual tests is prone to error.

@janosvitok @alexanderedge any volunteers? :)
Now it doesn't seem to cause tests to fail. The few remaining failures seem to be caused by some other reasons not related to my change. Could you check?
